title: 111_s3972
content: The Act is titled the "National Blue Alert Act of 2010" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act, titled the "National Blue Alert Act of 2010," defines key terms such as Coordinator, Blue Alert, Blue Alert plan, network, and State. The Act defines key terms for the National Blue Alert Act of 2010, including United States Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The Attorney General will establish a national Blue Alert communications network to issue alerts in coordination with various entities. A Blue Alert Coordinator will be appointed to provide guidelines for the network. The Attorney General appoints an officer to coordinate the Blue Alert communications network. The Coordinator's duties include encouraging the development of Blue Alert plans, establishing guidelines for issuing alerts, and protecting law enforcement's privacy and autonomy. The Blue Alert system ensures the independence and autonomy of law enforcement officers and their families. Alerts are only issued when there is confirmation of death, serious injury, or attack on an officer. The Blue Alert system issues alerts when a law enforcement officer is seriously injured or killed in the line of duty, and the suspect involved has not been apprehended. Descriptive information of the suspect and relevant vehicle details are required for the alert. The Blue Alert system issues alerts when a law enforcement officer is seriously injured or killed in the line of duty. Information on the suspect should be provided to the National Crime Information Center database and relevant state repositories. Blue Alerts should be limited to geographic areas most likely to facilitate suspect apprehension. The Blue Alert system allows for seamless communication between law enforcement agencies across states, with guidelines for issuing alerts and suspending them once the suspect is apprehended or when the alert is no longer effective. The Blue Alert system includes developing protocols for apprehending suspects, coordinating with states for regional efforts, and regulating public safety communications, command center operations, and incident review procedures. The Blue Alert system involves establishing an advisory group to assist in initiating, facilitating, and promoting Blue Alert plans, with representation from various geographic regions and members from law enforcement, broadcasters, first responders, and other relevant organizations. The Coordinator plays a crucial role in the success of the Blue Alert network by acting as the nationwide point of contact for development and regional coordination. Participation in the guidelines, protocols, and programs is voluntary, and dissemination of information is done in consultation with law enforcement agencies. The guidelines for Blue Alerts ensure appropriate dissemination of information to law enforcement agencies, public health agencies, and other relevant entities. Privacy and civil liberties protections are included to comply with all applicable laws and regulations, specifically focusing on protecting the privacy and civil liberties of injured or killed law enforcement officers and their families. The Coordinator for Blue Alerts will cooperate with various agencies and submit reports to Congress on the effectiveness of Blue Alert plans. SEC. 5. GRANT PROGRAM FOR SUPPORT OF BLUE ALERT PLANS. Section 1701(b) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to assist states in developing or enhancing Blue Alert plans, including education and training programs, law enforcement programs, and associated equipment. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to assist states in developing Blue Alert plans and implementing new technologies for improved communication. Section 1001(a)(11) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to authorize $10,000,000 for grants under section 1701(b)(17) for fiscal year appropriations for part Q, with funds remaining available until expended.
